abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Second Road
            Maintenance Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability
            as likely, institutional development impact as modest, Bank
            performance as satisfactory, and Borrower performance as
            satisfactory. Lessons learned from the project are as
            follows: 1) Structure without a strategy hardly produces the
            intended results. In this case the Decentralization
            Administrative Law shows that the lack of a clear and
            comprehensive strategy led to a faulty situation. 2)
            Strategies require comprehensiveness in their approach.
            Without a sustained strategy for the financing of road
            maintenance, the effect of physical investments is
            short-lived. The absence of a financing strategy derailed
            one of the key objectives of the project: the establishment
            of a sustainable approach for the maintenance of road
            assets. 3) Incentives for institutional reform must be
            established from the outset or built into specific progress
            steps within a project implementation timetable. 4)
            Procurement must take place immediately after the completion
            of designs, and designs must be complete, to avoid the
            frequent situation of recurring to change orders to adjust
            to changes in the conditions of the project area. The role
            of transport and the related investments as a
            countercyclical mechanism for economic growth is critical.
            As a general lesson, there is a need to strengthen the
            mechanisms for the internalization of knowledge into
            implementing institutions.
